title: 112_s3084
content: The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends title 38 of the United States Code to establish 12 geographically defined Veterans Integrated Service Networks aligned with the Department's mission and specific healthcare requirements of veterans. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network implements national goals and maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations. The Secretary oversees regional budgets for Veterans Health Administration activities in the Network, ensuring alignment with Department guidelines and balancing budgets annually. They also use national metrics to develop efficient healthcare delivery systems rated highly satisfactory by patients and families. The Secretary ensures high quality clinical programs and services are provided in the Network, reducing duplication of functions in clinical, administrative, and operational processes. The Secretary ensures collaboration and cooperation within each Veteran Integrated Service Network to maximize patient care, safety, education, and research effectiveness. This includes assessing consolidation or realignment of functions in collaboration with other networks and relevant offices/entities in the geographical area. The Secretary ensures collaboration and cooperation within each Veteran Integrated Service Network to maximize patient care, safety, education, and research effectiveness. This includes the following offices or entities within the geographical area of the Network: The offices of the Veterans Benefits Administration and the National Cemetery Administration, the offices, installations, and facilities of the Department of Defense, including each branch of the Armed Forces and the reserve components, the offices, installations, and facilities of the Coast Guard, and offices of State and local agencies. The Secretary ensures collaboration within each Veteran Integrated Service Network with various entities including offices of State and local agencies, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community and faith-based organizations, and other Federal Government offices as deemed appropriate. The Secretary ensures that Veterans Integrated Service Networks develop and share innovations and best practices at local, regional, and national levels. Each network is to have one headquarters office located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, with a limit of 65 full-time equivalent employees and contractors. The Secretary oversees Veterans Integrated Service Networks, each with a headquarters limited to 65 employees and contractors. Annually, a report on employment at these headquarters must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs, detailing the number of individuals employed at each network's headquarters. The report on employment at Veterans Integrated Service Networks' headquarters includes the number of individuals employed, their titles, and the budget impact. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting a report to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report includes an assessment of the budget impact of employing individuals at the Networks' headquarters. The Secretary conducts a triennial review of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks' structure and operations, submitting a report to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs with recommendations for improvement. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the relevant title. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single networks based on geographic regions. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is consolidating multiple Veterans Integrated Service Networks into single networks based on geographic regions. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 11 and 12, 15 and 23, and 17 and 18 will be combined into single networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks are being consolidated based on geographic regions. Networks 19 and 20, as well as networks 21 and 22, will be combined into single networks. Headquarters consolidation is also planned. The Secretary will retain one headquarters for each set of consolidated Veterans Integrated Service Networks and eliminate any additional headquarters to meet specified requirements. Reemployment assistance will be provided for individuals whose positions are eliminated. The Secretary will provide reemployment assistance to individuals whose positions are eliminated due to headquarters consolidation. Within 180 days of the Act's enactment, a plan to implement this assistance must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary may relocate a headquarters office of a Veterans Integrated Service Network to be co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center upon the expiration of a lease. The Secretary may relocate a headquarters office of a Veterans Integrated Service Network to be co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center upon the expiration of a lease. If the Secretary renews or enters into a new lease for the headquarters, a report must be submitted to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs explaining the reasons for the renewal or new lease. The report must include a list of underutilized buildings in VA medical centers, their square footage, current lease costs, and new lease costs. The report should detail the cost of the new lease, including annual rent, total cost over the lease term, and cost per square foot, along with the square footage to be leased. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Each center will report to the Under Secretary of Health and perform specified functions. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate the quality of work in finance operations and compliance activities within Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Assessment areas include outreach to veterans of specific operations and programs for women veterans. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate the quality of work in finance operations and compliance activities within Veterans Integrated Service Networks. This includes assessing programs addressing homelessness among veterans, energy consumption, and other relevant operations. Staff may be hired as needed for these functions. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate finance operations and compliance activities within Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The location of each center will be determined by the Secretary and may be co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. Alternatively, a center may be located elsewhere with approval from the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate finance operations and compliance activities within Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Before leasing a location, a report must be provided explaining why a regional support center is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The report should include a list of underutilized buildings in the network, the number of buildings, and total underutilized square footage for each medical center in the network. The Secretary will establish regional support centers to evaluate finance operations and compliance activities within Veterans Integrated Service Networks. When leasing a location, a report must justify why a regional support center is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The report should list underutilized buildings in the network and the total underutilized square footage for each medical center. Initial staffing for these centers will involve transferring employees from headquarters to regional support centers. The Secretary will establish regional support centers within Veterans Integrated Service Networks, transferring employees from headquarters to cover functions similar to those described in section 7309A(b) of the title. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 73. The Act establishes regional support centers within Veterans Integrated Service Networks, without requiring changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
